intro: Lagarinthus hispidus, commonly known as the hairy moonflower, is a flowering plant native to the southern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the nightshade family (Solanaceae) and is characterized by its fragrant, white to pale purple flowers that open at night. The plant typically grows as a shrub or subshrub, with hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers are tubular and have five lobes, with a distinctive scent that attracts nocturnal pollinators like moths. The fruit is a capsule that contains numerous small, smooth seeds.
